item.title: Will They Inherit Our Blogs?
item.dc:creator: Kev Quirk
item.description: I've been thinking about how this site may be able to live on after I'm gone. Maybe it could become a family heirloom?
item.content:encoded:
I've been thinking about how this site may be able to live on after I'm gone. Maybe it could become a family heirloom?

I‚Äôve thought about this topic more generally before, but this one is specifically about blogging.

This blog is by far the hobby I have sunk the most time into over the last 13-ish years, and I‚Äôd like to think I‚Äôll continue as I head from middle age, to old age. Let‚Äôs say I live until I‚Äôm 80, I will have spent over 50 years of my time on this earth writing content here at kevquirk.com.

I don‚Äôt want all the hard work to disappear in a puff of smoke once I snuff it, so I‚Äôve been thinking. Could this blog become a family heirloom?. Could I pass this site on to one (or both) of my sons and have them continue to write here?

They wouldn‚Äôt even need to continue to use kevquirk.com. They could write on their own domain(s), and just redirect this one.

I like to think that many of the other long-time bloggers out there might want the same. Maybe one day it‚Äôll be normal to leave our blogs to our kids?

A question worth asking

I do think it‚Äôs something we should consider. I‚Äôm part of the first generation that grew up online, and most of us are still very much alive. But as time marches on, more of us are going to leave behind these digital epitaphs.

I‚Äôd love it if my sons took up blogging when they‚Äôre old enough to (that, and riding motorbikes!). But they‚Äôre their own people, and may not want to. If that‚Äôs the case, I just hope they‚Äôll agree to keep my waffle online for a little while once I‚Äôm gone. ü§∑üèª‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

item.title: When Was I Happiest?
item.dc:creator: Kev Quirk
item.description: My wife recently asked me at what point in my life was I the happiest. The answer surprised her.
item.content:encoded:
My wife recently asked me at what point in my life was I the happiest. The answer surprised her.

First, a little context. I‚Äôm currently in my early 40s. I‚Äôm married with 2 kids, many pets, and lots of other responsibilities. According to this site I am in the top 1% of earners in the UK (that‚Äôs not a flex - the relevance will become apparent later).

So 2 lovely kids, lots of animals, a beautiful home in the countryside, nice cars on the drive, and 2 motorbikes in an incredible garage. I should be the happiest I‚Äôve ever been, right?

Wrong.

The happiest I‚Äôve ever been was when I was in my mid 30‚Äôs, when it was just me, my wife, and 1 dog (who‚Äôs now getting very old and it breaks my heart). Back then I was earning around ¬£100,000 less than I earn today. We lived in a much smaller house. We had older cars that needed regular repairs and maintenance. Generally speaking money was tighter, we had 1 pet, no kids.

But life was simpler then. I worked in a role I enjoyed and was good at, with far less stress (I‚Äôve recently taken steps to get some of that balance back). We would go for long walks with the dog at weekends, then cuddle up on the sofa in the evening to watch a film with a glass of wine. I had time to exercise, to visit friends, to just do what I wanted.

This was when I was at my happiest, and it really shocked my wife.

So you regret having the kids and you‚Äôre now unhappy?

That was her response, and she was so wrong.

Happiness is a scale

The misunderstanding here is that happiness is binary. You‚Äôre either happy, or unhappy. But that‚Äôs simply not true. I‚Äôm happy now, but I was happier then.

How could I be unhappy now? Sure I have a stressful job, far less free time, and a dog that I love dearly that only has a couple years left if we‚Äôre very lucky. But I also have 2 wonderful kids, a beautiful and supportive wife, and many other animals that I also love. We also have money in the bank, which lets us do nice things without worrying. We have security.

The rare times when my wife and I do get to curl up on the sofa with the dogs and a glass of wine mean far more to us these days, as they‚Äôre so rare.

But the simplicity of my life a decade ago made me so much happier. I don‚Äôt wish I‚Äôd stayed there, though. Life moves on. We mature, we progress, we change. And I‚Äôm happy those things have happened to me, and continue to happen to me.

My hope now is that my kids will grow up and start their own lives. My wife and I will pay off the mortgage on our house and (hopefully) retire in our mid-late 50s. At which point life will become simpler again and we can enjoy each other‚Äôs company for many more years. And as we grow old together, we can look back on a life that was well-lived, and happy. That‚Äôs enough for me.

item.title: Use the Bloody Shift Key!
item.dc:creator: Kev Quirk
item.description: I'm seeing a growing number of personal blogs that don't use upper case letters and for some reason it really irks me.
item.content:encoded:
I'm seeing a growing number of personal blogs that don't use upper case letters and for some reason it really irks me.

One of my favourite ways to discover new and interesting personal blogs is on the Bear Blog discovery feed but there‚Äôs a trend I‚Äôve noticed recently where a number of sites on Bear simply don‚Äôt use uppercase letters. Like, at all.

Now, I‚Äôm no grammar gremlin - goodness knows that my own grammar is far from perfect, and I have absolutely no problem if there‚Äôs an errant comma here and there in one‚Äôs writing. I could even forgive you if you were one of those lunatics that does CAPS ON types uppercase letter CAPS OFF. At least you‚Äôre using uppercase. But to remove all uppercase letters with reckless abandon? Nope. Absolutely not.

The weird thing is, I don‚Äôt see this anywhere else. It‚Äôs literally just on the Bear Blog Discovery feed. I have a lifetime account on Bear Blog, so I know that Herman doesn‚Äôt require his members to hand in their shift key when they sign up. So what‚Äôs it all about? Does anyone know?

The irony is that pretty much all of the posts I see do contain other punctuation. It‚Äôs just the humble uppercase letter that has had the chop.

I‚Äôm not going to link to specific blogs/posts here, but if you go check out the Bear Blog discovery feed you will likely see a handful of posts with no uppercase letters; a pattern which often infects the entire post, unfortunately. As I write this, 6 of the 20 posts on the front page of Discover are lowercase.

Personally, I can‚Äôt abide it. When I come across one of these posts, even if the title sounds genuinely interesting, I just can‚Äôt bring myself to read the content. Instead, I end up focusing on the obvious lack of uppercase letters. I know I‚Äôm missing out on interesting posts because of this, and that makes me sad.

Please, for the love of all that‚Äôs UPPERCASE and holy, stop doing it. ‚ù§

</rant>

item.title: Linux in the Air
item.dc:creator: Kev Quirk
item.description: Sal talks about how Linux is going through somewhat of a revival at the moment, as well as some of his own thoughts on the whole Mac vs Windows vs Linux debacle, and I wanted to add some of my own thoughts.
item.content:encoded:
Linux in the Air

by Sal

Sal talks about how Linux is going through somewhat of a revival at the moment, as well as some of his own thoughts on the whole Mac vs Windows vs Linux debacle.

Read Post ‚Üí

I think a lot of this Linux revival is thanks to a perfect storm going on in the OS space, namely:

  • Microsoft forcing many users to buy new hardware because of arbitrary hardware requirements, as well as forcing users to have an online accounts.
  • Apple completely screwing up MacOS Tahoe with their Liquid Glass update.

I‚Äôve been back on Linux (specifically Ubuntu) since I bought my Framework 13, and I‚Äôve been very happy. The only issues I‚Äôve really had are with some apps being blurry under Wayland, but I‚Äôve been able to easily work around these issues. Sal has had some similar problems with Wayland, but has also managed to work around them.

My son also runs Linux on his iMac, and I‚Äôm about to replace Windows 10 on my wife‚Äôs X1 Carbon with Ubuntu too. So we‚Äôre going to be a Linux household very soon.

And you know what? It‚Äôs fine. My son doesn‚Äôt know (or care) that he‚Äôs running Linux. My wife will be in the same boat - as long as she can check her emails, browse the web, and manage our finances in a spreadsheet, she‚Äôs good.

Linux based operating systems are great, and I‚Äôm thrilled they‚Äôre going through this revival. If you‚Äôre thinking about switching, I‚Äôd implore you to do so - remember you can always try before you ‚Äúbuy‚Äù with a live USB. So there‚Äôs no commitment required.

If you do switch, please remember to donate to your distro of choice. ‚ù§

item.title: The Case for Blogging in the Ruins
item.dc:creator: Kev Quirk
item.description: In a web dominated by feeds and algorithms, Joan makes a strong case for blogging as a way to reclaim depth, ownership, and real thinking.
item.content:encoded:
The Case for Blogging in the Ruins

by Joan Westenberg

Joan makes the case that the modern web, dominated by platforms and algorithms, has stripped away depth, ownership, and genuine thought. Blogging, she argues, is a quiet act of resistance that lets us think clearly, write freely, and leave something real behind.

Read Post ‚Üí

I‚Äôm not sure where I first heard about Joan and her superb writing, but I‚Äôve been following her for around a year or so now, I think.

Anyway, I was catching up on my RSS feeds and came across this post from a few days ago. It‚Äôs fantastic, as it most of what Joan puts out.

Start a blog. Start one because the practice of writing at length, for an audience you respect, about things that matter to you, is itself valuable. Start one because owning your own platform is a form of independence that becomes more important as centralized platforms become less trustworthy. Start one because the format shapes the thought, and this format is good for thinking.

I couldn‚Äôt agree more.

item.title: How You Read My Content (The Answers)
item.dc:creator: Kev Quirk
item.description: Two days ago I published a simple survey asking how you read the content I put out on this site. Here's the results of that survey.
item.content:encoded:
Two days ago I published a simple survey asking how you read the content I put out on this site. Here's the results of that survey.

Originally I was going to leave the survey running for at least a week, but after less than 48 hours, I received an email from Zoho telling me I‚Äôd hit the monthly response limit of 500 responses. If I wanted more responses, I‚Äôd have to pay.

Nah. 500 responses is enough to give me a good indication on how people consume my content, so I was good with that. Also, 500 responses in less than 48 hours is bloody brilliant. Assuming only a small proportion of readers actually responded (as that‚Äôs usually the case with these things) that means there‚Äôs a healthy number of you reading my waffle, so thank you!

The results

The survey simply asked ‚Äúhow do you read the content I put out on this site?‚Äù and there were a handful of options for responses:

  • RSS
  • Mastodon / Fediverse
  • Email
  • Occasionally visit the site
  • Something else

If someone selected the last option, a text field would appear asking for more info. There were a few people who used this option, but all were covered by the other options. People just wanted to add some nuance, or leave a nice message. ‚ù§

So I updated all the something else responses to be one of the other 4 options, and here‚Äôs the results:

A highly accurate pie chart

Option Responses %
RSS 421 84.5%
Masto/Fedi 38 7.6%
Visitor 27 5.4%
Email 12 2.4%

What this tells me?

Well, quite a lot, actually. It tells me that there‚Äôs loads of you fine people reading the content on this site, which is very heart-warming. It also tells me that RSS is by far the main way people consume my content. Which is also fantastic, as I think RSS is very important and should always be a first class citizen when it comes to delivering content to people.

I was surprised at how small the number was for Mastodon, too. I have a fair number of followers over there (around 13,000 according to Fosstodon) so I was expecting that number to be a bigger slice of the pie.

Clearly people follow me there more for the hot takes than my waffle. üôÉ

This was a fun little experiment, even if it did end more quickly than I would have liked. Thanks to all ~500 of you who responded, really appreciate it.

See, you don‚Äôt need analytics to get an idea of who‚Äôs reading your stuff and how.

item.title: I've Pre-Ordered the Clicks Communicator
item.dc:creator: Kev Quirk
item.description: I've yearned for a Blackberry form-factor for years, and now Clicks have made that wish come true. I had to pre-order one!
item.content:encoded:
I've yearned for a Blackberry form-factor for years, and now Clicks have made that wish come true. I had to pre-order one!

If you don‚Äôt know what the Clicks Communicator is, this 12 minute video should help:

BlackBerry‚Äôs design will always have a special place in my heart. I much prefer a physical keyboard over a touchscreen, and I‚Äôve said many times that smartphones are far too big these days.

The Clicks Communicator is smaller and it has a proper QWERTY keyboard. It is all very BlackBerry, and I love that.

The team have also teamed up with the Niagara Launcher developer to deliver a more focused UI. That was yet more good news for me, as I already use Niagara Launcher on my Pixel 9a.

It felt like a match made in heaven, so I pre-ordered one immediately.

Companion device?

In all honesty, I do not understand why Clicks are marketing the Communicator as a companion device. I assume they are positioning it as a slimmed down alternative for people who still want a flagship phone, but that framing feels odd.

It will be running full fat Android 16, and their FAQ confirms (in the very first question, no less) that the Communicator can be used as a primary device. That is exactly how I intend to use it.

The companion device messaging is confusing. At first, I assumed it was something closer to the Light Phone, but it is not that at all. It‚Äôs a normal phone. I am not a marketer, so perhaps there is a strategy here that I am missing, I just hope it does not hurt their sales.

Either way, I am genuinely looking forward to receiving my Clicks Communicator later this year. I will, of course, write about it once it arrives.

Has this cool new phone piqued anyone else‚Äôs interest?

item.title: How Do You Read My Content?
item.dc:creator: Kev Quirk
item.description: I'm trying to get an idea on how people consume the waffle I put out, it should only take 5 seconds to respond, and I'd be very grateful.
item.content:encoded:
I'm trying to get an idea on how people consume the waffle I put out, it should only take 5 seconds to respond, and I'd be very grateful.

It‚Äôs well publicised that I don‚Äôt run any kind of analytics on this site. For me, engagement is far more important. But I‚Äôm trying to better understand how you fine people consume the waffle I spit out into the world.

The only reason I want to do this is that I think it will be interesting to know. I could temporarily add tracking to the site, but that feels icky to me; I‚Äôd rather have something that‚Äôs opt in. So I‚Äôve created a really simple form that you can fill in. It only has 1 question, so should take no more than a few seconds to complete.

If you‚Äôre a regular reader, I‚Äôd be very grateful if you could take a few seconds out of your day to cast a vote please. The form is embedded below, but it may not embed properly in some places (like on the RSS feed), so just in case here‚Äôs a direct link to the form too.

I‚Äôve removed the embedded form now, as I‚Äôve already hit the maximum amount of responses that Zoho allows on their free forms package. Thanks to everyone who responded!

item.title: Good Riddance, 2025
item.dc:creator: Kev Quirk
item.description: I'm glad to see the back of 2025, so let's focus on 2026.
item.content:encoded:
I'm glad to see the back of 2025, so let's focus on 2026.

As I write this, it‚Äôs 18:49 on New Year‚Äôs Eve. I‚Äôm sat in the lounge, with the fire going, annoyed that our NYE plans have been ruined by me having the flu.

I feels like an appropriately shitty end to a very shitty year.

In 2025, I:

  • Worked way too much
  • Spent too much time away from home travelling for work
  • Neglected those I love
  • Helped my Mum, where possible, through recovering from a heart attack
  • Lost my sister

Yeah, it‚Äôs been rough. But toward the end of the year I made some decisions to make my life more sustainable. So I‚Äôm going to try and not dwell on the past, but instead look forward to the future.

As I look to 2026, I want to:

  • Eat healthier and lose weight
  • Exercise more
  • Spend more time with loved ones
  • Stop being such a shitty friend and make more of an effort

There‚Äôs more I want to do, but if I can get these done, I‚Äôll consider 2026 a win.

We‚Äôll see‚Ä¶

item.title: Is Firefox Firefucked?
item.dc:creator: Kev Quirk
item.description: I've been using Firefox for over 20 years at this point, but after a stream of cock-ups, I'm thinking about moving on.
item.content:encoded:
I've been using Firefox for over 20 years at this point, but after a stream of cock-ups, I'm thinking about moving on.

I‚Äôve been using Firefox since 2005, so not long after it was first released. I distinctly remember the first time I heard about it - I was on a training course with the Army and the instructor was using Firefox. Netscape was effectively dead, and everyone was using Internet Explorer, but I‚Äôve always been a magpie for the new shiny, so when I saw his browser, I asked him about it.

He told me about it being a fork of Netscape (which was my browser of choice when I first started using the Internet), so I jumped on board and have been happily using Firefox ever since.

Well, I was happy up until the last few years.

Slow decline

I first wrote about my concerns with Firefox‚Äôs direction back in 2022 where I talked about the ever increasing CEO salary, despite their ever decreasing market share, their teaming up with Meta on Interoperable Private Attribution (IPA), them shilling cryptocurrencies, and of course the fact they‚Äôre pretty much entirely funded by Google.

Well, over the last 3 years, things haven‚Äôt gotten any better and my concerns around the direction Mozilla is taking Firefox have continued to rise.

On top of the few concerns I had back in 2022, there‚Äôs a bloody list of additional concerns I‚Äôve picked up since then:

  • Privacy Preserving Attribution (PPA) - In Sept 2024, Mozilla rolled out this new PPA feature that was enabled by default and helped advertisers measure performance without traditional tracking.
  • Adjusted telemetry in mobile app - Firefox mobile versions shipped with a third-party telemetry SDK (Adjust) that sent usage and install data without prominent user disclosure. After pushback, this was later removed [slow clap].
  • Buying an Ad firm - yes, that‚Äôs right, dear reader. Everyone‚Äôs favourite FOSS web browser decided to buy an ad firm, because, you know, ‚Äúprivacy-centric adverts‚Äù.
  • We won‚Äôt sell you data, pinky promise‚Ä¶ - in early 2025 a formal Firefox Terms of Use was introduced, which included a clause granting Mozilla a ‚Äúnon-exclusive, royalty-free, worldwide licence‚Äù to use user-entered data. At the same time, they quietly removed explicit ‚Äúnever sell user data‚Äù language from privacy messaging. Brilliant.
  • What‚Äôs the strategy? - as we move to mid-2025 it started to become clear that Firefox‚Äôs leadership is out of touch with their users.
  • Firefox to evolve into an AI browser - that‚Äôs right, according to their new CEO Firefox is set to ‚Äúevolve into a modern AI browser‚Äù.

Mozilla‚Äôs strategy problem (and why AI is just a symptom)

Mozilla have been getting a lot of shit for the last few days about the whole modern AI browser comment their new CEO made. And rightly so, I think. To me, there‚Äôs a clear difference between a browser that has AI capabilities embedded in it, like an AI chat bot, and an AI browser.

The latter aren‚Äôt browsers. They‚Äôre an abstraction layer between you (the user) and the web, summarising, filtering, and rewriting it before you ever see the original, and I have no desire to be a part of that mess.

I don‚Äôt mind having a browser with a chat bot embedded in it, as long as it can be switched off. I‚Äôd prefer for it to be opt-in, but meh, if it‚Äôs only a rocker switch in settings, while annoying, I can live with it.

But having this layer of abstraction between me and the web that I know and love? No thank you.

I‚Äôm worried about the direction Firefox is headed in. Not just because of their AI strategy; I actually think that‚Äôs a symptom, not the root cause.

The root cause, as I see it, is that the leadership team at Mozilla has no fucking clue how to make Firefox a sustainable business, so they‚Äôre just throwing shit at the wall and hoping something sticks. All while giving their CEO larger and larger salaries.

Because Mozilla has been suckling on Google‚Äôs teat since the very early days, they‚Äôve never had to make a sustainable business. Google dodged the bullet and wasn‚Äôt ultimately forced to sell Chrome, but it exposed just how dependent Mozilla still is on Google‚Äôs money, and now it looks like they‚Äôre scrambling to invent a strategy of their own.

But it‚Äôs shit, and as a long-term user of Firefox, it feels almost user-hostile at this point.

So what now?

Honestly, I don‚Äôt know. I‚Äôve been dabbling in other browsers, but haven‚Äôt found anything I like as much as Firefox.

While I appreciate the sentiment, I‚Äôm not looking for browser recommendations. So please don‚Äôt contact me with recommendations. By all means contact me with your opinions on all this though.

Vivaldi has too many bells and whistles for my liking, plus there‚Äôs a number of UI inconsistencies that annoy me. Brave has all the crypto nonsense embedded, but it can be switched off. Then there‚Äôs forks like Librewolf and Waterfox, but they‚Äôre intrinsically tied to upstream Firefox, and they don‚Äôt have mobile apps. So I‚Äôm not sure they‚Äôre a good option, either.

Correction from future Kev: Waterfox does in fact have an Android app.

Firefox won‚Äôt be changing to a modern AI browser any time soon, so there‚Äôs no rush for me to jump right now. So I‚Äôm planning to continue testing alternatives and just hope that the Mozilla leadership team have a course correction. But if the last few years have taught me anything, it‚Äôs that a course correction is unlikely to happen.

item.title: The Fisherman and The Businessman
item.dc:creator: Kev Quirk
item.description: I didn't expect a parable about a fisherman to smack me in the face with such clarity, but here we are.
item.content:encoded:
I didn't expect a parable about a fisherman to smack me in the face with such clarity, but here we are.

While reading Grow slowly, stay small on Herman‚Äôs blog, I learned about The Fisherman and The Businessman, which goes like this:

A businessman meets a fisherman who is selling fish at his stall one morning. The businessman enquires of the fisherman what he does after he finishes selling his fish for the day. The fisherman responds that he spends time with his friends and family, cooks good food, and watches the sunset with his wife. Then in the morning he wakes up early, takes his boat out on the ocean, and catches some fish.

The businessman, shocked that the fisherman was wasting so much time encourages him fish for longer in the morning, increasing his yield and maximising the utility of his boat. Then he should sell those extra fish in the afternoon and save up until he has enough money to buy a second fishing boat and potentially employ some other fishermen. Focus on the selling side of the business, set up a permanent store, and possibly, if he does everything correctly, get a loan to expand the operation even further.

In 10 to 20 years he could own an entire fishing fleet, make a lot of money, and finally retire. The fisherman then asks the businessman what he would do with his days once retired, to which the businessman responds: ‚ÄúWell, you could spend more time with your friends and family, cook good food, watch the sunset with your wife, and wake up early in the morning and go fishing, if you want.‚Äù

‚Äì Herman Martinus

Ah man, preach! This resonated so much because I recently realised that I‚Äôm The Fisherman. Well, to be more accurate, I was The Fisherman posing as The Businessman. Now I‚Äôm just The Fisherman, and it‚Äôs lovely.

Since stepping down as an executive I‚Äôve become happier, got far more job satisfaction, and I spend more time with my family. I‚Äôve also realised that a lot of what was driving me was ego. I wanted to be important. I wanted the fancy title, the corner office, the prestige.

I wanted the job for all the wrong reasons.

I‚Äôm not saying all execs are egomaniacs. I‚Äôm saying my reasons for chasing that level were mostly ego. That‚Äôs on me.

At this point I have what I think is the perfect balance between pay, free time, and job satisfaction. I love my job again and I‚Äôm really fucking happy.

What‚Äôs the point of this post? Honestly, I have no idea. I just wanted to share this great little parable and say thanks to Herman for sharing it originally. If you‚Äôre not happy with your job, maybe it‚Äôs worth asking which one you‚Äôre being right now.

item.title: Year 3 at the Smallholding
item.dc:creator: Kev Quirk
item.description: We're been living on our smallholding in Wales for 3 years now. Here's how things have been going this year.
item.content:encoded:
We're been living on our smallholding in Wales for 3 years now. Here's how things have been going this year.

I‚Äôm a little late with my update this year because I‚Äôve had a few things going on at home. This has accidentally become an annual tradition at this point, so I‚Äôm gonna roll with it.

I re-read last year‚Äôs update to see what I did and, more importantly, what I‚Äôd listed in the closing what‚Äôs next? section. It included:

  • Renovating the brick shed on the drive into an annex for guests.
  • Continuing to work on the garden.
  • Insulating the roof in the conservatory.
  • Two more bathrooms, a downstairs loo, and the kitchen.

Well, dear reader, most of that plan went to utter rat shit this year. Aside from continuing to work on the garden, we got absolutely nothing on the list done. That‚Äôs mainly because we ended up having to replace the entire roof on the house, which is still ongoing as I write this.

Worse still, because the new roof is heading into winter, we‚Äôve had lots of rain. That in turn means leaks in the house, the worst of which has been in my oldest son‚Äôs bedroom. If you read last year‚Äôs post, you‚Äôll recall we only renovated that room last year. üò°

If you‚Äôve never had to put a new roof on your house, firstly you‚Äôre very lucky. But secondly, they‚Äôre really expensive. So that has meant we haven‚Äôt had any disposable income for other projects.

Making progress in the garden

We managed to plant some wildflowers in the far field, which one of our neighbours who keeps bees is very appreciative of.

Wild flowers starting to come through in field

We also had a load of groundwork done at the back to flatten some of it off. They ended up moving 50 tonnes of soil from the area to make it level. Our hope is that this summer we‚Äôll be able to enjoy drinks and barbecues on the new flat piece of land.

We‚Äôre also continuing to improve the chicken coop. We now have a fairly large enclosed outdoor space for them, mainly because of bird flu in the and the council applying restrictions on where they can roam. We‚Äôve also grown the flock to 17 hens and a rooster.

Looking to year 4

The list for this year is going to be similar to last year‚Äôs. I just hope there will be fewer expensive surprises.

We‚Äôre hoping to add a polytunnel so we can grow more of our own vegetables. I‚Äôd also like to insulate the roof in the conservatory as it‚Äôll effectively give us another room we can use all year round.

The bathrooms, toilet and kitchen will have to wait. We‚Äôll just have to see how the cashflow looks. If next year I can get the polytunnel and conservatory done, I‚Äôll class that as a win. I‚Äôd love to get a quad bike for towing the flail too, but again‚Ä¶money.

All in all it‚Äôs been a difficult year at the smallholding, but we have a new roof, so that‚Äôs good. I suppose‚Ä¶

item.title: How I Replaced My Son‚Äôs PC With an ¬£88 iMac
item.dc:creator: Kev Quirk
item.description: I recently replaced my son's broken PC with a 2015 iMac from eBay. Here's how it went...
item.content:encoded:
I recently replaced my son's broken PC with a 2015 iMac from eBay. Here's how it went...

A year or so ago, my wife and I gave our oldest son a spare computer we had lying around. This was mainly for homework, but also for some light gaming, like Minecraft and Super Tux Cart. The machine was actually the little home server I built a few years ago.

At 6 years old the motherboard decided to give up the ghost and blew. After talking to him about it, we decided to look for something a bit smaller and cool looking. Originally I was going to go with one of those Raspberry Pi keyboards, but they‚Äôre ¬£200 and would likely struggle playing Minecraft.

Then I read about someone loading Linux onto an old Mac with great success (I can‚Äôt remember who it was, so can‚Äôt provide a link I‚Äôm afraid). Anyway, I‚Äôve always loved the look of the old iMacs, so decided to have a peek on eBay for one.

I ended up finding a late-2015 21.5‚Äù iMac with 8GB RAM, a 1TB HDD, and a 4th Gen Core i5 processor for ¬£88, delivered!

For that price I wasn‚Äôt expecting much. But it looked clean in the pictures, so I decided to take a punt.

Getting the iMac

While waiting for it to arrive, I ordered CPU paste, adhesive strips for resealing the screen, and a RAM upgrade before realising the RAM is soldered on these models, so that was a bust. I also replace the tired old HDD with the 512GB SSD from my son‚Äôs previous machine.

I opened it up, replaced the paste, installed the SSD, and sealed it back up. The SSD already had Ubuntu Mate 22.04 on it with all his files and Minecraft maps, so I booted it and let the drivers sort themselves out.

A quick sudo apt update && apt upgrade -y later and everything worked perfectly. I also bumped it to 24.04 while I was there.

Here‚Äôs how the new machine looks on his little desk in his bedroom:

Pretty cool, I think you‚Äôll agree.

Performance

Oh lordy, this thing is quick! It boots up in a few seconds, every single app opens pretty much instantly, and he gets a stable 60+ FPS on Minecraft. He‚Äôs thrilled with it, and so are we. So much so that we will probably do the same thing again next year when we look to get a machine for our youngest.

Final thoughts

If you‚Äôre on the hunt for a new device, I‚Äôd seriously consider looking at an Intel Mac with Linux. They‚Äôre blazing fast, they look great, and are amazing value.

The only downside is that this window is closing. Apple‚Äôs move to the M-series chips means Linux support will be tougher over time. Projects like Asahi Linux exist, but support varies and the long-term outlook is unclear.

For now though, our oldest son has a solid machine that should last him for a few years. If it dies again, I‚Äôll probably look at a Framework 12, but hopefully it won‚Äôt come to that.

What do you think about running Linux on older hardware? Would you try something like this? Leave a comment or drop me an email and let me know.

item.title: Local vs Cloud
item.dc:creator: Kev Quirk
item.description: I was listening to the Waveform podcast on my way to work this morning and they were talking about cloud vs local computing, and I have thoughts...
item.content:encoded:
I was listening to the Waveform podcast on my way to work this morning and they were talking about cloud vs local computing, and I have thoughts...

I was listening to the Waveform podcast on my commute this morning when they started talking about cloud vs local computing. The discussion quickly drifted into hypotheticals about unlimited storage and choosing one world or the other.

But the whole debate felt off to me, because it rests on a bad assumption: that ‚Äúcloud‚Äù and ‚Äúlocal‚Äù are two totally separate things.

Defining ‚Äúthe cloud‚Äù

Before we can argue about cloud vs local, we need to be clear about what we‚Äôre comparing.

People talk about the cloud like it‚Äôs some mystical ether, but as the saying goes, it‚Äôs really just someone else‚Äôs computer. If it‚Äôs a machine you don‚Äôt own, sitting in a datacentre somewhere, it‚Äôs cloud.

By contrast, local doesn‚Äôt just mean ‚Äúthe laptop you‚Äôre holding‚Äù. It includes anything you own and control: your PC, a server in a cupboard, or a NAS on your home network.

Once you see it this way, the Waveform question becomes more interesting. Because I think local can include your own private cloud.

My approach

At home I use a Synology NAS as the centre of my own little ecosystem. It runs all the services I rely on daily, but with the convenience you‚Äôd usually expect from big cloud providers. A few examples:

  • Plex for media
  • Synology Photos for backing up images from my phone
  • Calendar and Contacts, all synced via DAV
  • Synology Drive for documents
  • My journal app
  • A notes app I use for Fediverse posts, so I have local copies of everything I post

Everything lives on hardware I control, but it‚Äôs still available wherever I am.

Backups are handled locally (to a USB drive connected to the Synology) and off-site (to Backblaze B2, encrypted before upload). The result is a system that behaves like a cloud service, but where I hold the keys.

Here‚Äôs my extremely high-quality architectural diagram:

No, I never studied art.

What about security?

I‚Äôm not going to get into specifics for obvious reasons, but the short version is that my Synology isn‚Äôt exposed to the Internet at all. My router only accepts traffic from specific networks, so I connect over VPN. It‚Äôs always-on for me and my wife, so the experience is completely transparent.

If you‚Äôre thinking of building something like this, I‚Äôd strongly recommend not exposing any part of your home network directly to the Internet.

So‚Ä¶ cloud or local?

Back to the original question. The unlimited storage bit doesn‚Äôt matter; you only need enough storage, not infinite.

Given the choice between 100% cloud or 100% local, I‚Äôd choose local every time. Not because I want to avoid cloud-like features, but because local gives me the same benefits without giving away control. My photos sync automatically, I can share links to files, edit documents anywhere, and my data is backed up properly.

The truth is that the whole premise of cloud vs local is a false choice. You don‚Äôt have to pick one at the expense of the other.

You can have the convenience of the cloud running entirely on hardware you own. The real choice isn‚Äôt cloud or local, it‚Äôs whose cloud you want to rely on.

What do you think? Do you lean toward cloud, local, or something in between? Feel free to leave a comment or drop me an email, I‚Äôd love to hear how you approach it.

item.title: Static Site Generators
item.dc:creator: Kev Quirk
item.description: Jan talks about how static site generators are far more complicated than WordPress, despite (ironically) their output being far simpler.
item.content:encoded:
Static Site Generators

by Jan van den Berg

Jan talks about how static site generators are far more complicated than WordPress, despite (ironically) their output being far simpler.

Read Post ‚Üí

I enjoyed this post from Jan once I‚Äôd translated it from Dutch and could actually read it. He talks about the irony of how the output of a static site generator is so simple, yet they‚Äôre somehow difficult to set up and maintain.

Since I‚Äôve been around the block when it comes to blogging platforms, I have some thoughts on this.

While talking about his time testing Jekyll, Jan says:

Ruby dependency mess, this is not what anyone wants, drama.

I get where he‚Äôs coming from. Dependency issues with Ruby can be annoying. But honestly, I can‚Äôt say I‚Äôve had any real problems with Jekyll while using Ubuntu. For me it‚Äôs been as simple as following the install instructions, running a quick bundle install, and I was off to the races.

Yes, setting up a static site is definitely more involved than installing WordPress. I completely agree there. But once it‚Äôs up and running, I‚Äôve found there‚Äôs very little ongoing maintenance. The worst it gets for me is when a gem updates and I need to run bundle update before getting back to work.

WordPress, on the other hand, has always been more frustrating for me to manage. There‚Äôs just so much noise in the admin UI. So many panels, so many settings, so much stuff most people will never touch. And then you have plugins, their updates, their banners, their upsells. It becomes‚Ä¶ messy.

That said, if you‚Äôre willing to ignore those frustrations, WordPress can be simple. Especially if you stick to an off-the-shelf theme and don‚Äôt tinker.

The truth is, it‚Äôs great that we have all these options. Different people have different expectations, preferences, and levels of comfort. Some folks want a managed dashboard full of knobs and switches. Others want a quiet folder of Markdown files and a build command.

I don‚Äôt agree that static site generators are inherently more difficult than WordPress. It really comes down to the use case and the person using the tool.

Anyway, go read Jan‚Äôs post ‚Äî it‚Äôs interesting. And if you have opinions, drop me an email or leave a comment below.

item.title: Adding Comments to My Jekyll Site
item.dc:creator: Kev Quirk
item.description: I've been working on adding support for comments over the last few months. On a static site, that's hard, but it's finally done.
item.content:encoded:
I've been working on adding support for comments over the last few months. On a static site, that's hard, but it's finally done.

A few months ago Maurice Renck and I were having a conversation on the Fedi (I think) and he mentioned that he would prefer to leave a comment than send me an email. Since then I‚Äôve also seen a few other people talk about how they like to see a comments section on blogs. So while I‚Äôve been pissing about with Jekyll recently, I decided to build a commenting system for this site.

Why not use something that already exists?

That‚Äôs a fantastic question, dear reader, and the answer is that all the solutions I‚Äôve found are either too expensive, not privacy focused, or don‚Äôt appear to be getting regular updates.

<RANT>
Why are commenting systems so bloody expensive? Like, they‚Äôre pretty simple, so why on earth does it cost more than the VPS that hosts the entire site to have what basically equates to an embedded form and a teeny-weeny DB that stores maybe a few hundred KB of plaintext?

Especially when a very small percentage of people are likely to bother leaving a comment.
</RANT>

Annnnyyyyywwwwwwaaaaaayyyyyy‚Ä¶‚Ä¶.

For the last month or so, I‚Äôve been working away on creating my own commenting system that has the features that I‚Äôd want to see, which are:

  1. Independent of the site they work with so they can be easily removed if I want to (embedded by loading a JS script).
  2. Be privacy focussed - no tracking or requirements to login/create an account.
  3. Send email notifications via Amazon SES when someone submits a new comment, or when someone replies to your comment (if you provided an email).
  4. Have a simple admin UI where I can approve/delete comments before they‚Äôre published, and reply.

My little commenting system is now live available at the bottom of this and every other post on this site. I‚Äôm fully expecting there to be the odd bug - if you find any, please do let me know.

Here‚Äôs a peek at what the admin UI looks like when someone comments (right-click > open in new tab to enlarge):

What‚Äôs next?

I‚Äôm thinking about releasing the source code for this so other folk can have a commenting system on their own site.

I‚Äôm also considering developing this to a point where I can offer it as a hosted solution for others to use, but I‚Äôm not sure I want that in my life. If I do, it won‚Äôt be expensive.

In the meantime, if you want to leave a comment, the form is below.

item.content:encoded:
RE: Why Do You Need Big Tech for Your SSG?

by Loren Stephens

Loren posts a response arguing that while self-hosting and local builds have their charm, the simplicity and zero-maintenance nature of services like Netlify often make them the more practical choice for small personal sites.

Read Post ‚Üí

I enjoyed this post as it approaches the problem I wrote about yesterday from a completely different perspective. While I spoke about rolling my own infrastructure and building locally to maintain control, Loren talks about the simplicity and cost (free!) of hosting with services like Netlify.

Loren closes his post by saying:

If you‚Äôre running a complex site or you‚Äôre philosophically opposed to big platforms, a VPS + rsync pipeline might be worth it. [‚Ä¶] For my tiny, low-traffic static site, the convenience, zero cost, and redirect handling of GitHub + Netlify are hard to beat.

I think this is the crux of the whole discussion. For me, it‚Äôs more about control than being opposed to big platform. I think they have their place, but for my use case, my personal blog isn‚Äôt it. For Loren, it‚Äôs all about simplicity and just getting shit done.

It‚Äôs fantastic that we have different options that allow for more control, or for ease of use. As a result, we have a diverse pool of people and opinions on the Indie Web, and I don‚Äôt think anyone can argue against that being a good thing.

item.title: Why Do You Need Big Tech for Your SSG?
item.dc:creator: Kev Quirk
item.description: A look at why small, personal websites don‚Äôt need big-tech static hosting, and how a simple local build and rsync workflow gives you faster deploys, more control, and far fewer dependencies.
item.content:encoded:
A look at why small, personal websites don‚Äôt need big-tech static hosting, and how a simple local build and rsync workflow gives you faster deploys, more control, and far fewer dependencies.

OK, so Cloudflare shit the bed yesterday and the Internet went into meltdown. A config file grew too big and half the bloody web fell over.

How fragile.

It got me thinking about my fellow small-web compatriots, their SSG workflows, and why on earth so many rely on services like Cloudflare Pages and Netlify. For personal sites it feels incredibly wasteful: you‚Äôre spinning up a VM, building your site, pushing the result to their platform, then tearing the VM down again.

Why not just build the site on your local machine? You‚Äôre not beholden to anyone, and you can host your site anywhere you like.

  • ‚úÖ No CI/CD pipeline.
  • ‚úÖ No big tech ‚Äî just you and your server.
  • ‚úÖ No VMs spinning up and down at the speed of a thousand gazelles.

How to build and deploy automatically

All you need is a hosting package that supports SSH (or FTP if you must) and a small script to build your site and rsync any changes. Here‚Äôs the core of my deployment script:

#!/bin/bash
set -e

LOCAL_DIR="/path/to/your/site/source"
REMOTE="user@your-server.example.com"
REMOTE_DIR="/path/to/your/website/files/yoursite.com/public_html"

cd "$LOCAL_DIR" || exit 1

# --- Build Jekyll site ---
echo "üèóÔ∏è  Building Jekyll site..."
bundle exec jekyll build --quiet
echo "‚úÖ Build complete"

# --- Sync _site to remote server ---
echo "üöÄ Deploying to server..."
rsync -az --checksum --delete --omit-dir-times --quiet \
  "$LOCAL_DIR/_site/" \
  "$REMOTE:$REMOTE_DIR/"

# --- Fin ---
echo "‚úÖ Deployment complete"

Here‚Äôs what it does:

  1. Jumps into the directory where my source website files live.
  2. Builds the Jekyll site locally.
  3. Syncs the built files to my server over SSH, deleting anything I‚Äôve removed locally.

That‚Äôs it. And that‚Äôs all it needs to do. With these few lines of Bash, I can deploy anywhere, without waiting for someone else‚Äôs infrastructure to spin up a build container.

My full script also checks the git status, commits changes, and clears the Bunny CDN cache, but none of that‚Äôs required. The snippet above does everything Cloudflare Pages and similar services do ‚Äî and does it much quicker. My entire deploy, including the extras, takes about eight seconds.

Final thoughts

If you‚Äôre hosting with one of the big static hosting platforms, why not consider moving away and actually owning your little corner of the web? They‚Äôre great for complex projects, but unnecessary for most personal sites.

Then, the next time big tech has a brain fart, your patch of the web will probably sail right through it.

Small Web, Big Voice

by Andre Franca

Andre argues that independent blogging isn‚Äôt about scale at all, but about integrity ‚Äî choosing a place you control, writing in your own voice, and keeping the web human.

Read Post ‚Üí

I read this post this morning while I was perusing my RSS feeds with a coffee. Firstly, I‚Äôm not sharing this because Andre called out my blog (although being bundled with people like Rach and Manu is extremely flattering). I‚Äôm sharing it because I agree with everything he says in the post.

Having a place on the web that I‚Äôm 100% in control of, where I can share my own thoughts, feelings, and opinions is very powerful for me. Over time this blog has evolved from me sharing technical posts most of the time, to a legit personal blog with a technical twist.

Despite what sites like ProBlogger say, I don‚Äôt have a niche, and I don‚Äôt try to grow my audience (I don‚Äôt even know how big my audience is). I just write whatever is on my mind at any given time, and people usually get in touch with me to discuss the topic. It‚Äôs fantastic.

If you‚Äôre on the fence about starting a blog, I implore you to do so. It‚Äôs probably the best thing I‚Äôve ever done with a computer. If you, please drop me an email with the link - I love discovering new blogs!

item.title: Giving My Jekyll Site a CDN Front End
item.dc:creator: Kev Quirk
item.description: I've managed to get my Jekyll based site working behind Bunny CDN, while maintaining my .htaccess redirects. Here's how I did it...
item.content:encoded:
I've managed to get my Jekyll based site working behind Bunny CDN, while maintaining my .htaccess redirects. Here's how I did it...

Since switching back to Jekyll recently, I‚Äôve been running this site on a Ionos-hosted VPS, then using a little deploy script to build the site and rsync it up.

This all worked fine, but I really wanted to use Bunny CDN for more than just hosting a few images and my custom font. Being a static site, I could have dumped everything onto their storage platform, but I have a metric tonne of redirects in a .htaccess file from various platform migrations over the years.

Bunny‚Äôs Edge Platform could have handled these, but with the number of redirects I have, it would have been a slog to maintain. So I assumed I‚Äôd never be able to put Bunny in front of my Jekyll site easily and went about my business.

üí° Then I had an epiphany.

What if I created a Bunny pull zone that uses kevquirk.com as the public domain, then set up a separate domain on my VPS, host the site there, and use that as the pull zone origin?

My theory was that Bunny would still be requesting content from the VPS, so my .htaccess redirects might still work.

‚Ä¶turns out, they did.

Some small bugs

I duplicated my live site so I could experiment safely. The setup looked like this:

  • test.kevquirk.com - the domain configured in the Bunny pull zone
  • src.qrk.one - the origin domain on my VPS, where the site actually lives

The first thing I had to do was update the url field in my Jekyll _config.yml from kevquirk.com to test.kevquirk.com, rebuild the site, and upload it to src.qrk.one.

Now, you might be thinking, ‚ÄúKev, why build the site with the wrong domain?‚Äù

But I haven‚Äôt. By building the site with the test domain, all links point to test.kevquirk.com/.... If I built it with the origin domain, all internal links would lead to the wrong place. They would still work, but the site would be served from src.qrk.one, which is not what I want.

Next up was redirect testing. I visited /feed, which should hit .htaccess and redirect to /feed.xml. The redirect worked fine, but the resulting URL was being served from the origin domain.

So instead of seeing test.kevquirk.com/feed.xml I saw src.qrk.one/feed.xml.

This happened because Bunny requested the file from the origin using its own hostname, not the hostname I typed. In simple terms:

  • I visited test.kevquirk.com/feed.
  • Bunny checked its cache. It wasn‚Äôt there, so it asked my origin for the file.
  • But Bunny made that request using its own hostname (src.qrk.one), not the one I typed.
  • Apache saw the request coming from src.qrk.one/feed and applied the .htaccess redirect to /feed.xml.
  • Apache then rebuilt the redirect URL using the hostname it was given, which was src.qrk.one.

So Apache went:

‚ÄúOh, you want /feed? Sure. That‚Äôs at src.qrk.one/feed.xml. Here ya go‚Ä¶‚Äù

Fixing the problem

This would not break anything for visitors, but I didn‚Äôt want src.qrk.one appearing anywhere. It looked messy.

Two changes fixed it:

  1. Enable Forward Host Headers in my Bunny pull zone.
  2. Add test.kevquirk.com as a domain alias of src.qrk.one on my VPS.

Forward Host Headers makes Bunny tell the VPS the hostname the visitor used. So instead of:

‚ÄúI‚Äôm asking for this on behalf of src.qrk.one.‚Äù

Bunny says:

‚ÄúI‚Äôm asking for this on behalf of test.kevquirk.com, not src.qrk.one.‚Äù

The domain alias ensures Apache accepts that hostname and serves it correctly.

Magic. ü™Ñüêá

The other thing to double-check is that every page sets a proper canonical URL. The origin domain is publicly accessible, so crawlers need to know which domain is the real one. That should always be the Bunny pull zone domain.

In Jekyll this is simple. Add the following to the head section of your layout:

<link rel="canonical" href="{{ page.url | absolute_url }}">

The final straight

With the redirect behaviour sorted, the last step was to add a purge step to my deploy script so Bunny knows to fetch the latest version whenever I publish a new post or update something.

Here‚Äôs the snippet I added:

# --- Clear Bunny Cache ---
echo "üóë Clearing Bunny Cache..."
PURGE_RESPONSE=$(curl -s -o /dev/null -w "%{http_code}" -X POST \
  -H "AccessKey: $BUNNY_ACCESS_KEY" \
  "https://api.bunny.net/pullzone/$PULL-ZONE-ID/purgeCache")

if [ "$PURGE_RESPONSE" -ne 200 ] && [ "$PURGE_RESPONSE" -ne 204 ]; then
  echo "‚ö†Ô∏è  Bunny purge failed (HTTP $PURGE_RESPONSE)"
  exit 1
fi

I set my Bunny API key and Pull Zone ID as variables at the top of the script. The if statement simply says, ‚ÄúIf the response isn‚Äôt 200 or 204, tell Kev what went wrong.‚Äù

And that is it. Last night I flipped the switch. Bunny CDN now sits in front of the live site. I also moved the VPS from Ionos to Hetzner because Ionos now charge extra for a Plesk licence. I went with Hestia as the control panel on the new server.

If you spot any bugs, please do let me know, but everything should be hopping along nicely now. (See what I did there? God I‚Äôm funny!)
